Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Phosphatidylcholine-Deoxycholate Injections for Abdominal Fat Reduction

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised by the final digit of their Social Security numbers

Participants.evidence: Thirteen women with a BMI <30 kg/m² and suitable lower abdominal fat were enrolled between July and November 2008.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised by the final digit of their Social Security numbers to receive PC-DC injections on one side of the abdomen, with the contralateral side as control.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates their effects on body composition and adipocyte function.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in adipose tissue thickness, measured 8 weeks after the final treatment.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomised by the final digit of their Social Security numbers

Blinding.evidence: Randomisation was not concealed, and neither patients nor clinicians were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Thirteen women with a BMI <30 kg/m² and suitable lower abdominal fat were enrolled between July and November 2008.

Result_Outcome.evidence: PC-DC treatment significantly reduced anterior subcutaneous abdominal fat thickness (mean difference = 4.1 cm, 95% CI 1.4 to 6.8; p = 0.004).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events included mild to moderate local reactions, with no serious adverse events reported.
